description: Variation of Condition 2 (Approved Plans) of Planning Permission ref: 19/01076/FUL (Erection of single storey building for use as a management suite and reception. Internal and external alterations to existing buildings to facilitate refurbishmentof existing student accommodation, including installation of PVpanels, with associated parking and landscaping arrangements) dated 10/09/2019. (Please refer to accompanying covering letter for proposed changes)
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of planning permission ref: 19/01076/FUL dated 10.09.2019.Reason: As required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990, as amended by Section 51 of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004

The car parking, servicing and manoeuvring areas shown on the approved drawings shall be provided with a hard, bound, dust-free surface, adequately drained before the development is occupied for the purpose hereby permitted. The respective areas shall be kept free from obstruction at all times, and shall not thereafter be used for any other purposes other than those shown on the approved drawing.Reason: To ensure that the proposed development does not prejudice the free flow of traffic or conditions of general safety on adjoining highways and that adequate parking servicing and manoeuvring provision is made in accordance with Policies DM9 (Managing Vehicle Use for New Development) and Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No building or use hereby permitted shall be occupied or the use commenced until the cycle parking provision shown on the approved plans has been completed, and thereafter, be kept free of obstruction and available for the parking of cycles only.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate cycling facilities in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development hereby approved shall be carried out in accordance with the Travel Plan approved by application ref: 19/02819/CLC  dated 14.01.2020. The approved Travel Plan shall then be implemented, monitored and reviewed in accordance with the agreed travel Plan Targets to the satisfaction of the council. The Travel Plan shall be submitted for a period of five years from first occupation.Reason: To ensure that sustainable transport methods are encouraged and implemented in accordance with Policies CS5 (Reducing the Need to Travel) and CS6 (Sustainable Travel) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The Construction Logistics Plan/statement approved under application ref: 19/02710/CLC dated 16.12.2019 shall be adhered to throughout the construction period. Reason: In order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development hereby approved shall be carried out in accordance with the Car Park Management Plan approved by application ref: 20/01426/CLC dated 14.08.2020.Reason: In order to promote sustainable travel and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policies DM9 (Managing Vehicle Use for New Development) and Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

With the exception of the photovoltaic panels which shall be  in accordance with the details approved by application ref: 20/01303/CLC dated 23.10.2020,  detailed drawings at a scale of 1:10 / 1:20 of the following shall be submitted to and be approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority before the relevant part of work is begun:a) detailed elevations of alterations to western elevation of Walkden Hall,including entrance area.b) details of the proposed facing materialsThe development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved details. Reason: In the interests of visual amenity and the character of the area. These details are required prior to commencement of development to ensure the development would have a satisfactory appearance.

The development shall be implemented fully in accordance with the recommendations and measures set out within the submitted Preliminary Ecological Appraisal prepared by Brindle Green (March 2019). Reason: To safeguard and protect the sites biodiversity and nature conservation value in accordance with Policy DM6 (Biodiversity) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development hereby approved shall be carried out in accordance with the detailed landscaping scheme approved under application ref: 19/02929/CLC  dated 23.01.2020. The approved scheme shall be implemented within the first planting season following completion of the development and the tree planting and landscaping shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority. Any trees or shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced in the first available planting season, and the area shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose only.Reason: In the interests of visual amenity and also that the Local Planning Authority shall be satisfied as to the details of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Consultations6no. surrounding properties were notified of the proposed development. No comments received.ProposalThe application seeks planning permission for the demolition of existing conservatory and erection of single storey rear extension. Site and SurroundingsThe site comprises of a detached two-storey dwelling located in Tangmere Grove.  The site does not comprise of a listed building, nor is it located within a conservation area or local area of special character. Planning AssessmentThe key considerations in the assessment of this application are:-	Character and Appearance; -	The Impact upon Residential Amenity; and-	Fire SafetyCharacter and Appearance Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Council's Supplementary Planning Document 'Residential Design' sets out guidance for single-storey rear extensions (under Policy Guidance 33), as follows:Depth: -	If the neighbouring house is set at a lower level, the depth of the extension should be reduced. -	If the neighbouring property has a different rear building line, then the depth of the extension could be increased.-	In all cases, at least 50% of the rear garden should remain. (Rear extensions to houses with very small gardens will be assessed on their individual merits.) -	Extensions should generally not exceed 3-3.5m in depth.Height:-	Extensions proposed with: -	a flat roof should not exceed 3m in height; -	a parapet roof should not exceed 3.3m in height; -	a pitched roof should not exceed 4m in height; and, -	a balcony or roof terrace will not be considered acceptable where it causes overlooking. The exception to this may be where the building sits on a large plot with adequate screening along any shared boundaries.The proposed single-storey rear extension would not be visible from the streetscene, contained behind the existing built form. The design of the extension is simple with a flat roof and 3no. flat rooflights inset. The proposed rear extension would extend most of the width of the dwelling. The depth of the proposed rear extension would measure to 4m, to a height of 3.3m. Whilst officers recognise that the depth would not adhere to Council's guidance set out in the Residential Design SPD, the scale in context of its plot and the relationship to neighbouring properties is considered to be acceptable in this particular instance. The proposals are assessed as generally in accordance with Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames LDF Core Strategy (Adopted April 2012) and the Residential Design SPD (Adopted July 2013).Impact upon Residential AmenityPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 requires new development to deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity. Policy DM10 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012) is clear that development proposals should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers consider that the proposed development, would have an acceptable impact on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers.The proposal is considered in accordance with Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames LDF Core Strategy (Adopted April 2012) and the Residential Design SPD (Adopted July 2013).Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development would accord with the relevant policies of the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), and Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Core Strategy (2012).The proposal by virtue of its scale, design and materiality is considered to be proportionate to the host dwelling and would not result in harm to the character and appearance of the host dwelling or wider area. In addition, the proposals would not result in materially harmful impact to neighbouring amenity by way of overlooking, loss of light or sense of overbearing or enclosure. Recommendation:That planning permission be GRANTED.

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises a mid terrace dwelling.The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.Proposal Erection of single storey rear extension.Consultations6 properties were notified of the proposal. One representations has been received with comments summarised as follows:- Inappropriate design/layout- Flank wall to be constructed of fair faced brick work in pale colour. Officer response: The above concerns will be addressed within the report.Relevant Plannign History23/00990/CPU Erection of single storey side/rear extension granted on 06.06.2023The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed extension would project approximately 2.85m beyond the existing outrigger line and the infill element of the proposal would be approximately 6m deep. It is acknowledged that the proposed single storey rear extension would not be strictly in accordance with Policy Guidance 33 of the Council's Residential Design SPD with regards to the recommended depth which is up to 3.5m. However, given that the extension would be to the rear only and would not be visible within the streetscene it is considered to be acceptable from a character and design perspective. With regards to the proposed materials - painted render, it would be similar to the existing one and therefore acceptable.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: Based on the submitted information the proposed extension would fail the 45 degree rule in relation to the closest ground floor habitable opening at the adjoining property No 46 Mount Road resulting in an unacceptable loss of daylight in relation to this property. Furthermore, due to the proposed depth of the infill extension of approximately 6m along the site boundary at a height of 3m, the proposal would appear overbearing and would result in an undue sense of enclosure in relation to No 46. Officers note the certificate of lawfulness granted for 3m extension ref no 23/00990/CPU, however the current proposal is considered to have a materially greater impact then the lawful development certificate given the significant increase in size proposed by the planning application proposal.With regards to No 42 Mount Road, given the siting and scale of the proposal it is considered not to adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of this neighbouring property by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be contrary to the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

The assessment of this application is based on measurements taken from the submitted drawings / plans. If it transpires that the drawings / plans submitted are incorrect this would nullify the validity of this decision and you are advised to submit a fresh application with the correct information / drawings.

Officers note planning permission ref no 22/01576/HOU granted on 08.07.2022 for:Conversion of garage into habitable space, Erection of two storey side and single storey rear extension, erection of rear dormer roof extension with Juliet balcony and installation of 2 nos front rooflights to facilitate loft conversion. Roof alteration. The applicant is reminded that implementing this development in combination with another development, whether pursuant to permitted development rights, a prior approval or a planning permission could render the totality of the works unlawful. This is particularly the case where the proposals would physically adjoin. The applicant is strongly advised to seek further advice before proceeding with any approval.

If you have evidence to contradict the local planning authority's assessment of the application, you are encouraged to apply for the development again and include that evidence in support of the application.

Consultations6no. surrounding properties were notified of the proposed development. No representations received.Planning History23/00444/HOU - Conversion of garage to habitable accommodation following a single storey front extension including new porch. Installation of new front door and side rooflight, and changes to fenestration. Refused planning permission, dated 20.04.2023 for the following reason:(1)	Due to the excessive projection at the front, the proposed extension would constitute a disproportionate and dominant addition that would detract from the character and appearance of the host property and the surrounding area, resulting in unacceptable harm to the character and appearance of the surrounding area, contrary to Policies D3 of the London Plan 2021, DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy April 2012 and Policy Guidance 38 of the Council's Residential Design SPD (2013).ProposalThe application seeks planning permission for the conversion of the existing garage to habitable accommodation with changes to front and side fenestrations. Site and SurroundingsThe site comprises a semi-detached dwelling located on Elgar Avenue.The site is not subject to any particular land use designations or environmental constraints.Planning AssessmentThe key considerations in the assessment of this application are:-	Character and Appearance; -	The Impact upon Residential Amenity; -	The Impact upon Highways; and -	Fire SafetyCharacter and Appearance Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.The proposals seek to convert the integral garage into a habitable space with associated change from existing garage door to a window of a similar appearance to the existing main windows within the front elevation of the property. This is considered to be an acceptable alteration which would not result in any harm to the overall character and appearance of the host dwelling. To the side elevation an existing door would be blocked up and a small high level window would be added.Having regard to the above officers consider that there would be no material impact from the proposed development on the character and appearance of the area.Impact upon Residential AmenityPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 requires new development to deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity. Policy DM10 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012) is clear that development proposals should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.The conversion of the garage and alterations to the fenestration would not cause any materially harmful impacts to neighbouring amenity.Accordingly, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of residential amenity.Impact upon HighwaysPolicy DM10 of the Core Strategy states that proposals should have regard to local traffic conditions and highway safety and ensure that they are not adversely affected. The application involves the conversion of the integral garage space. Despite the loss of the existing garage, it is considered that the hardstanding to the front of the dwelling remains of an adequate size to accommodate one off street car parking space. Therefore, the proposals would not result in an unacceptable impact on the local highway network.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy. Officers are satisfied that the proposal adequately meets the requirements of Policy D12(A). Ongoing compliance with the strategy would be secured through conditions, in the event of a favourable recommendation.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development would accord with the relevant policies of the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), and Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Core Strategy (2012).The proposal is considered not to result in harm to the character and appearance of the host dwelling or wider area. In addition, the proposals would not result in materially harmful impact to neighbouring amenity. In addition adequate car parking space for the property would be retained to the frontage, to the satisfaction of the Council.Recommendation:That planning permission be GRANTED.

Condition 4 (Arboricultural Method Statement) of planning permission 22/03324/HOU states:Prior to commencement of the development (including any works of demolition), a detailed arboricultural method statement and tree protection plan shall be submitted to and approved by the Local Planning Authority.  This submission shall include:A plan to a scale and level of accuracy appropriate to the proposal, that shows the positions, crown spreads and root protection areas (RPA) of every retained tree on site, and on nearby ground or land adjacent to the site, in relation to the approved plans.A schedule of pre-construction works for the above-detailed trees, where appropriate.Calculated dimensions and positions of all tree root protection areas.Details and positions of tree protection barriers and ground protection where appropriate.Details and positions of any construction exclusion zones.Details and positions of the existing and proposed underground service runs, to be routed to avoid root protection areas where possible and if not possible, for alternative methods of installation to be detailed within the AMS.Details and positions of any change in levels or positions of any excavations within 5m of the root protection area of retained trees.Details of any special engineering required to accommodate proposals within the root protection areas of retained trees (e.g. in connection with foundations, service installation, bridging, water features, surfacing).Details of the working methods to be employed for the installation of drives, paths or any other form of hard surfacing within the root protection areas of retained trees in accordance with the principles of 'No Dig' construction. All details shall be in accordance with British Standard BS5837: 2012 "Trees in relation to Design, Demolition and Construction"The approved protection scheme shall be implemented prior to commencement of any work on site including demolition, and be maintained to the reasonable satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority until the completion of the development or until such stage as detailed within the approved AMS.Reason: To safeguard trees worthy of retention and in the interests of the character and appearance of the area, in accordance with policy G7 of the London Plan 2021 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.This condition must be a pre-commencement condition in order to be effective.Officer response: The Council's Tree Officer is satisfied with the revised information provided for Condition 4 (Arboricultural Method Statement) of planning permission 22/03324/HOU. As such, details submitted for Condition 4 are hereby approved.Condition  7 (Fire Safety Strategy) of planning permission 22/03324/HOU states:Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, Fire Safety information (a Strategy) shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The  Strategy shall demonstrate how the development will achieve the highest standards of fire safety and shall include the following details: 1) suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point; 2) Appropriate fire alarm systems; 3) Passive and active fire safety measures;4) appropriate construction details to minimise the risk of fire spread; 5) provision of suitable and convenient means of escape/ an evacuation strategy; 6) provision of suitable access and equipment for firefighting which is appropriate for the size and use of the development. The Strategy shall include a statement of competence. The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved Strategy and thereafter maintained.Reason: In the interests of fire safety and to ensure the safety of all building users in accordance with Policy D12 (Fire safety) of the London Plan 2021.Officer response: The submitted Fire Safety Strategy is considered to be sufficient.  As such, details submitted in relation to Condition 7 are hereby approved.

23/01332/HOUThe application site is located to the north of Berrylands and is currently occupied by a two storey detached residential dwelling with forecourt parking to the front and a rear garden. The site is located in a largely residential area and opposite Surbiton Racket and Fitness Club. The existing building is not statutorily listed or a locally listed building and the site is not located within a Conservation Area. The site is in flood zone 1.6 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and 2 no. objections were received.-	Excessive in size-	Concern it will be converted to habitable accommodation-	Concern over flouting planning process -	A condition is included on the parent permission which restricts outbuildings without prior written approval of local planning authority Planning HistoryAny relevant planning history for the site has been taken into account in considering this application and recent planning history is available to view on the Council's website.23/00148/FUL - Application under Section 73 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 to carry out development without compliance with Conditions 1 (Approved Plans) of Planning Permission ref: 22/00420/FUL (Demolition of existing dwelling and erection of two storey replacement dwelling with rooms in loft space and new vehicle crossover) dated: 18/10/2022. Variation to consist of addition of single storey rear extension - Granted 20 Mar 202322/00420/FUL - Demolition of existing dwelling and erection of two storey replacement dwelling with rooms in loft space and new vehicle crossover - Granted 18 Oct 2022. The key areas of assessment are: - Design and character - Neighbour amenity  - Fire Safety Design and character Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. A single storey outbuilding has been practically constructed in the rear garden of the property, measuring approximately 9.2m in width, 3.5m in depth and 2.4m in height. Through planning application 22/00420/FUL, as varied by 23/00148/FUL, a replacement dwelling was granted planning permission. A condition was attached to this permission removing permitted development for outbuildings. The intent of this condition was not to prohibit outbuildings but, given the scope and range of building sizes allowed through Class E of the GPDO, to require planning permission to be sought for any outbuildings to ensure they were of an appropriate scale taking into account the increased size of the replacement dwelling. This application seeks to regularise the breach of planning control. In this case, the outbuilding is discretely sited at the rear of the garden and is not unreasonable in scale or height and a rear garden of over 200sqm would be retained. Its design is also considered subservient to, and in keeping with, that of the approved replacement dwelling. For these reasons, the outbuilding is not considered to result in harm to the character and appearance of the area.As such, the proposal is in accordance with Policy D3 and HC1 of the London Plan (2021) and Policies CS8 and DM 10 and DM12 of the Core Strategy (2012) and Residential Design Guide SPD (2013).AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment:The outbuilding is modest in scale and height and sited away from neighbour boundaries. It is therefore not considered overbearing or likely to result in an undue loss of daylight and sunlight for adjoining neighbours.In summary, the proposal is not considered to result in an undue loss of amenity for surrounding neighbours, in accordance with Policy DM10 of the RBK Core Strategy (2012).Fire Safety AssessmentLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer Comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy. The plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.Overall the development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan and as such, planning permission is recommended for approval, subject to the conditions listed above.

Application SiteThe site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.ProposalErection of a single storey side/rear extensionConsultation13 neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire SafetyDesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: It is noted that several properties in the area have been extended in a similar fashion adn the extension would not be highly prominent within the street scene. Overall, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: With regards to neighbouring amenity, the principal properties to consider are No. 14 Egmont Avenue and also the rears of the properties adjoining the site from Egmont Road. Due to the separation distance, coupled with the lack of windows at first floor level, no harm has been identified to the properties on Edmont Road. In relation to No. 14 Egmont Avenue, the proposed rear element would comply with BRE guidance in relation to the nearest habitable window. It is therefore considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyPart A of Policy D12 (Fire Safety) of the London Plan (2021) sets out that "In the interests of fire safety and to ensure the safety of all building users, all development proposals must achieve the highest standards of fire safety and ensure that they: 1) identify suitably positioned unobstructed outside space:   a) for fire appliances to be positioned on   b) appropriate for use as an evacuation assembly point2) are designed to incorporate appropriate features which reduce the risk to life and the risk of serious injury in the event of a fire; including appropriate fire alarm systems and passive and active fire safety measures 3) are constructed in an appropriate way to minimise the risk of fire spread4) provide suitable and convenient means of escape, and associated evacuation strategy for all building users 5) develop a robust strategy for evacuation which can be periodically updated and published, and which all building users can have confidence in6) provide suitable access and equipment for firefighting which is appropriate for the size and use of the development.Officers Comments: While no Fire Statement has been submitted to demonstrate how the proposed development addresses the requirements of Part A of Policy D12 of the London Plan (2021), Officers consider that the proposal should be able to meet the requirements of Policy D12(A). Were the application otherwise acceptable, a Fire Strategy would be secured by way of a planning condition. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

All Householder applications that involve extensions must provide "45 Degree" floor and elevation plans. These should be drawn at a scale of 1:50 or 1:100, they should accurately identify neighbouring building(s) and window(s) and when possible indicate the use of the room served by the window(s), and should be annotated to show the application of the 45degree 'rule'. Please see the Householder Validation Local List for more information.

All Householder applications that involve extensions of 2 or more storeys must provide "25 Degree" Elevation Plans. These should be drawn at a scale of 1:50 or 1:100, they should accurately identify neighbouring building(s) and window(s) andwhen possible indicate the use of the room served by the window(s), and should be annotated to show the application of the '25 degree rule'. Please see the Householder Validation Local List for more information.
